title: London fire chief admits 'stay put' advice was not suitable for Grenfell as she calls for urgent research on 'buildings that fail'
text:
London Fire Brigade has called for the Government to carry out an urgent review of the controversial ‘stay put’ policy which led firefighters to tell people to remain in their homes as fire consumed Grenfell Tower.

Dany Cotton, the London Fire Commissioner, admitted on Wednesday the policy was not suitable for a building such as Grenfell, where the failure of basic fire safety features led the flames to engulf the 24 storey building in just half an hour.

She said the ‘stay put’ policy only worked in buildings where the fire was contained within the flat or apartment where it had started, something which did not happen at Grenfell, leading to the death of 72 people in the early hours of 14 June 2017.

Speaking just a few weeks before the publication of the first phase of the Grenfell Tower inquiry report, Ms Cotton told the Greater London Assembly’s Fire, Resilience and Emergency Planning Committee: “We are calling for urgent research on buildings that fail because buildings that fail mean ‘stay put’ advice is no longer viable.”

Ms Cotton has previously defended the policy of advising residents to stay in their flats in the event of fire as being suitable for high rise towers, telling the inquiry into the tragedy last year that the rapid spread of fire up the outside of the tower was so unexpected that firefighters were right to tell people to stay put.
description: London Fire Brigade has called for the Government to carry out an urgent review of the controversial ‘stay put’ policy which led firefighters to tell people to remain in their homes as fire consumed Grenfell Tower.
